title: Quiz 2: April 2016 Licensure Exam
description: Complete licensure examination covering Mental Health, Management, Research, and General Nursing from April 2016. Contains all MCQs, Short Answer, and Essay concepts.

questions.question: An involuntary psychiatric patient strikes the nurse and threatens to kill her while refusing medication. What is the most appropriate nursing action?

options.text: Decide not to administer the medication
Initiate the ordered, forced medication protocol
Initiate legal action to get the client declared incompetent
Teach the client the pros and cons of compliance

questions.explanation: In an emergency where a patient poses an immediate danger to others (violence/threats), forced medication (chemical restraint) is justifiable for safety.
questions.hint: Safety is the immediate priority over autonomy in a violent crisis.

questions.question: Benzodiazepines are primarily indicated for which of the following?

options.text: Short-term treatment of generalized anxiety disorder and alcohol withdrawal
Short-term treatment of obsessive compulsive disorder

questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines are indicated for short-term relief of anxiety, alcohol withdrawal, and pre-op sedation. They are generally avoided for long-term treatment due to dependence risk.
questions.hint: Think 'Short-term' and 'Anxiety'.

questions.question: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) development is most strongly influenced by:

options.text: Severity of stressor and lack of support systems

questions.explanation: PTSD risk is directly linked to the intensity/severity of the trauma (stressor) and the absence of protective factors like social support.
questions.hint: Think about external factors that define the 'Trauma' in PTSD.

questions.question: The ultimate goal of therapy for a client suffering from multiple personality disorder (Dissociative Identity Disorder) is:

options.text: Integration of the personalities into one

questions.explanation: The primary long-term therapeutic goal is integration (fusion) of the fragmented identities into a cohesive whole.
questions.hint: Making the many into one.

questions.question: With an overdose of barbiturates, death is most likely to occur from:
questions.explanation: Barbiturates are CNS depressants that suppress the respiratory center in the brainstem, leading to respiratory arrest.
questions.hint: These drugs put the brainstem to sleep, stopping breathing.

questions.question: Which strategy is appropriate for ensuring safety and environment when admitting a psychiatric emergency client?

options.text: Afford privacy, but not at the risk of compromising personal safety
Interview the client at close range
Keep minimal lighting to avoid stimulus
Depend solely on help from colleagues

questions.explanation: Privacy is important but physical safety is paramount. The nurse must not be trapped or isolated with a potentially dangerous patient.
questions.hint: Safety first, privacy second.

questions.question: For offenders with a history of alcohol misuse and violent offending, therapeutic approaches in prison should include:

options.text: Assessment by clinical officer and detoxification
Assessment by a specialist substance abuse service and detoxification
Severe restrictions in alcohol consumption only

questions.explanation: Effective management requires specialized assessment and treatment services, not just general medical care or punishment.
questions.hint: Special problems require specialist services.

questions.question: Teachers who choose to assess the effects of their teaching in order to improve on their practice are referred to as __________ practitioners.
questions.explanation: A reflective practitioner engages in self-analysis and evaluation of their teaching methods to improve future practice.
questions.hint: They look back at their work like a mirror.

questions.question: Which scenario introduces bias affecting the validity of standardized test scores?

options.text: Students using a geometric pattern on the answer sheet
Giving the entire class extra time to accommodate a few students
Selecting a test that matches taught skills
Students taking a different form of the same test previously

questions.explanation: Standardized tests require uniform administration conditions (time, instructions). Altering conditions for the whole group violates standardization.
questions.hint: Standardization means everyone follows the exact same rules.

questions.question: Freud's model of personality consists of:
questions.explanation: Freud's structural model consists of the Id (instincts), Ego (reality), and Superego (morality).
questions.hint: The three parts of the psyche.

questions.question: S breaks up with T because he cheated. S tells her friend K about it without showing any emotion. Which defense mechanism is S using?
questions.explanation: Isolation involves separating the memory of a traumatic event from its associated emotion, allowing one to speak of it calmly.
questions.hint: She has separated the feeling from the fact.

questions.question: The ability to communicate effectively:

options.text: Is a natural talent that cannot be learned
Depends on the education level of others

questions.explanation: Communication is a skill that can be acquired, practiced, and improved.
questions.hint: It is a skill, not just a talent.

questions.question: Standardized tests were originally developed for:

options.text: Selection and screening of army personnel

questions.explanation: Mass standardized testing gained prominence with the Army Alpha/Beta tests in WWI for screening recruits.
questions.hint: Think about World War I recruitment.

questions.question: When appraising statistical results, what is most important to understand?
questions.explanation: The P-value indicates statistical significance, helping determine if results are due to chance.
questions.hint: This value determines significance.

questions.question: Strategic planning primarily consists of:
questions.explanation: It encompasses the entire cycle: developing the plan (formation) and executing it (implementation).
questions.hint: Making the plan + Doing the plan.

questions.question: In general, if a policy is not thought out and established, what is the likely result?

options.text: A situation requiring action will arise
Managers will be hired from outside

questions.explanation: Policies guide decisions. Without them, situations will arise that require ad-hoc decisions, often leading to inconsistency or crisis.
questions.hint: The gap in policy creates a vacuum for problems.

questions.question: A diabetic client reports impotence and concern for his marriage. What is the most appropriate nursing intervention?

options.text: Suggest referral to a sex counselor/professional

questions.explanation: Sexual dysfunction is complex and requires specialized assessment and intervention beyond general nursing scope.
questions.hint: Refer to a specialist.

questions.question: The style of managing change associated with coercion or edict is best described as:

options.text: Use of authority to set direction

questions.explanation: Coercive change management involves forcing compliance through the explicit use of power and threats.
questions.hint: Forcing change through power.

questions.question: The primary role of the supervisor is to:

options.text: Help the subordinate develop effective ways of working

questions.explanation: Modern supervision focuses on development, guidance, and helping staff improve their own work processes.
questions.hint: Developmental role.

questions.question: Reducing health care costs and improving quality in Kenya can be achieved by:

options.text: Reducing overuse and misuse of health care services

questions.explanation: Efficiency requires eliminating waste, which includes both unnecessary services (overuse) and errors/incorrect care (misuse).
questions.hint: Eliminate waste and errors.

questions.question: Identify the requirements for a community psychiatric service for long-term care:
questions.explanation: Requirements include accessibility, skilled teams, crisis support, rehab, family involvement, and medication management.
questions.hint: What does a patient need to live successfully in the community?

questions.question: Identify clues that can help identify substance impairment in a nurse:

options.text: Frequent absenteeism or disappearing from the unit
Mood swings, irritability, or social isolation
Patients complaining of ineffective pain relief
Volunteering for shifts with heavy medication administration

questions.explanation: Signs include attendance issues, behavioral changes, signs of drug diversion (count errors, patient pain), and seeking access to drugs.
questions.hint: Look for behavioral changes and red flags with medicines.

questions.question: Outline the factors influencing curriculum development:
questions.explanation: Curriculum is driven by society needs, learner needs, regulations, resources, and knowledge expansion.
questions.hint: What shapes what is taught in schools?

questions.question: Select the correct classification of pain categories:
questions.explanation: Broad categories are Acute and Chronic. Sub-types include Somatic, Visceral, and Neuropathic.
questions.hint: Duration vs Origin.

questions.question: Which factors contribute to communication failures in healthcare?
questions.explanation: Failures are caused by human factors like fatigue, stress, hierarchy (fear of speaking up), and environmental distractions.
questions.hint: What makes it hard to talk to a doctor in a busy ward?

questions.question: Arrange Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs from lowest (base) to highest (top):
questions.explanation: Physiological -> Safety -> Love/Belonging -> Esteem -> Self-Actualization.
questions.hint: Survival first, growth last.

questions.question: Select the characteristics of Authoritarian Leadership:
questions.explanation: Authoritarian leaders retain power, dictate tasks, and demand compliance. This is effective in crises but generally lowers morale.
questions.hint: Like a dictator or commander.

questions.question: A patient presents with bruises in various stages of healing, injuries to the trunk, and is evasive about the cause. What are the priority nursing interventions for suspected abuse?

options.text: Ensure privacy and interview patient alone

questions.explanation: Priorities are safety (interview alone), medical care, documentation for legal purposes, and safety planning. Confrontation puts the victim at risk.
questions.hint: Protect the victim, treat the wounds, document the evidence.

questions.question: Match McGregor's Management Theories with their assumptions:

pairs.right: People dislike work and must be coerced/controlled
Work is natural; people seek responsibility and self-direction

questions.explanation: Theory X = Negative view (Lazy employees). Theory Y = Positive view (Motivated employees).
questions.hint: X is bad/strict; Y is good/participative.
